{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3556068,"name":"zombie","username":"zombiepyro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/dfb087/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T14:18:05.706Z","cooked":"

hi! i’m the coder for 5213 SHIELD and im brand new to it this year. our coder last year graduated and didnt leave us with many resources.
i’ve gotten so far as to being able to put in our swerve drive and our robot can drive (yay!) but i cant get the arm motors to go into the code. if i could get some help, that’d be great! thank you!

we use talon fx falcon 500 motors for the entire project!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T14:32:35.919Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":172,"readers_count":171,"score":84.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495444,"topic_slug":"i-m-a-new-coder-and-i-m-struggling-to-code-motors-need-asap-help","display_username":"Drakxii","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23134,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI "},"post_url":"/t/i-m-a-new-coder-and-i-m-struggling-to-code-motors-need-asap-help/495444/2","custom_user_title":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3556080,"name":"abuddies","username":"abuddies","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/abuddies/{size}/254804_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T14:45:16.087Z","cooked":"

I’m not exactly sure what language you’re coding in (Java, C++, Python), but I can provide example code in Java and some general advice.

Firstly, I would recommend writing some simple code that should work (to test and see if there’s any mechanical/electrical issues that need to be fixed before code can do anything).

// In Robot.java just for an example
TalonFX motor = new TalonFX(0); // 0 is the CAN port. You can change this to whatever you'd like by connecting to the robot and using Phoenix Tuner (an app you'll have to download).

public void teleopPeriodic() {
   motor.set(0.5); // This sets the motor to run at 50% maximum voltage/speed. 0 = 0% voltage. 1 = 100% voltage.
   // This should also work in teleopInit() as well. Calling motor.set() will continuously send voltage until either the robot is turned off or some other part of the code calls motor.set()
}

If this doesn’t work, I’d check a couple of things:

  1. While trying to run the motor with code, hold the motor. If it feels like it’s vibrating or getting hot, there’s probably something wrong with the gears or the key (this is a mechanical issue, not a code issue).
  2. Connect to the robot using Phoenix Tuner X (or just normal Phoenix Tuner). Make sure that the firmware is up-to-date, the port number is unique, and you could also try running the motor to see if it’s a gear problem.
  3. Look at the status lights and compare with these status lights. Make sure that you have a CAN connection and are sending a signal (normally, the status lights blink red at the same time when driving in reverse and green when driving normally. If they’re blinking alternately red, there is a connection issue)

for simple control to just move wheels use motor.setControl(new DutyCycleOut(double power(-1 to 1 based on power and direction desired)))

for positional control like with an Arm/Elevator you can set the motor to target a set position in internal motor rotations like this motor.setControl(new PositionDutyCycle(double rotations(target position in motor rotations))) make sure to set PID values and tune them, you could also try out MotionMagic for positional control.

if you use an absolute encoder on the pivot either fuse the encoder data when you config the motor or zero the motors internal encoder at the start of the code. alternatively without an absolute encoder you can use a backstop as your known start position to zero off of.
